newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ crossbred wool prices fall at Christchurch sale.
newsitem.headline: NZ crossbred wool prices fall at Christchurch sale.

text.p: Prices for crossbred wools fell at the sale in Christchurch, with the exception of fine crossbred fleece and stronger lambswool, Wools of New Zealand said on Friday.

The official market indicator was down 13 cents to 427 NZ cents per kg clean, with strong down nine to 369 and lamb down six to 380. On offer was 1,659 clean tonnes in 14,009 bales, chiefly comprising 49 percent crossbred fleece, 24 percent lambswool and 11 percent second shear.
Passings of wool which failed to meet growers' reserves amounted to 35.7 percent.
Compared with last week, crossbred fleece 33/34 micron was 1.0 percent dearer, 35 micron was unchanged while 36 micron and stronger was generally 1.5 to 2.5 percent cheaper.
Cotts were 2.0 to 3.0 percent cheaper, and second shear 2.0 to 4.0 percent cheaper.
First lambs 29 to 31 microns was 2.5 percent cheaper, but 31 to 33 percent microns was 2.0 to 3.0 percent dearer. Second lambs was 5.0 to 7.5 percent cheaper.
Bulky skirtings were generally 3.0 percent cheaper and Second shear bellies and pieces were 2.0 percent dearer.
